segments.text: ... I'm going to write you a letter and put it in with these tapes.
And then I thought, well, I might as well talk to you for a while on this other tape instead of writing a letter.
This is November the 28th, Thursday, November the 28th.
And the Phyllis has the parcels ready to ship -- Christmas parcels ready to ship to Toronto,
and Janey, and Calgary, I presume.
No, Calgary, they'll be down here.
They'll pick theirs up here.
Anyway, everything's going fine here.
We've got nice weather now the last three, four days.
I've been doing some work on my water softener.
The valve -- shut off valve on the water line.
It wouldn't shut off anymore.
It was all corroded.
And the one going into the pan on the humidifier has been leaking.
And I couldn't get it adjusted.
So I'm putting in a new valve, a new float valve.
Believe it or not, the little plastic thing, $12.75.
And I don't know how long it'll last.
The other one lasts about five, six years.
And then the orifice goes on them.
And you could put a new rubber gasket in, but it won't shut the water off.
And I had to run around and pick up the parts.
You've got to go here and you've got to go there.
One guy has one thing and the next guy has the other thing.
And between the two shopping malls here, I've been able to gather up the stuff I need.
And what else am I doing?
Yeah, I'm going to put a plastic, a stiff plastic cover in front of the
fireplace.
I've done some testing.
I put cardboard in there back when it was so cold.
What a difference it made in this familyroom.
You can't imagine the cold air that came out through that fireplace.
It's not a draft.
It's just a continuous cold coming in.
I put a cardboard in there and shut it all off tight
and you could sit in here and it was, 10, 15 below zero.
And your feet were nice and warm.
Where before that, just sit in here and your feet were always cold.
I talked to George the other day.
He phoned me, oh ya to tell me that he had been to the annual meeting of the Elks
where they give out their pins for the years.
Next year, I'm up for my 45th year as an Elk.
George is coming into his 50th in a year or so.
He's keeping fine.
Sounded good.
Said he had been talking to you guys.
I better check on this; see if it's taping properly.
Yeah, it seemed to be taping,
so all I have to do is lay back in the lazy boy here and talk.
If I can think of what to say, it's, you know,
unless you have some special topic to talk on,
it's pretty hard to keep on a continuous conversation.
I'm getting quite a kick out of all
the "bad news".
You never hear anything good on TV,
it's always bad.
Poor Reagan, he's into it up to his knees.
And I don't think our boys in Ottawa are much better.
They're trying to patch up here and patch up there
to make it look good but oh boy.
The old dept keeps on piling up, piling up.
Sinclair Stevens is having a hell of a time.
I laugh at when they're at the coffee roll.
I say, they shouldn't be so hard on that guy,
you know, I shook hands with him about 20 years ago
and he's a pretty nice fella.
You probably don't know that.
It was at the time that I was a signer for the Western Bank of Canada
that Stevens and Klein were going to start up.
And they were down here and had a meeting
in the Saskatchewan Hotel.
And all of us that were signers for were invited there.
You know, just to hear them talk.
But it's in the end, they never start the bank.
They got squabbling amongst themselves
who is going to control it.
And that's where it stopped.
But right now, it seems that Stevens has got himself
into plenty of a mess.
If what you can go by what you see here on TV.
It looks pretty rotten.
And that both him and his wife are just sitting there
telling one bit after the other.
Deny, deny, deny.
The fella that loaned her, what, 2.6 million
without knowing who she was.
Yeah.
I think he was lying a little bit, too.
However, that's all past -- let'er go.
Right today on the news, it came over -
you talk about bad news -
and the news for this morning, I heard that there was
a policeman in Calgary that had robbed 20,
had staged 20 bank holdups in Calgary
in the last couple of years.
He's a policeman.
33 years ago.
Father of a family of seven, and a very unassuming guy.
And I don't know how they got suspicious, but they,
I guess they followed him after hours or something
and caught him in the act and tanked plenty of robberies
off to him.
Whether he was responsible for all of them, I don't know.
That's some more bad news.
The first time I saw him, I thought, well, this is bad news.
First minister's meeting in Vancouver,
I listened to it for nine hours.
They all did a magnificent job of consenting their case.
But each one ended up the next day,
then holding his hand out, give us some money,
give us some money, we need this, we need money to do that.
Well, Rudy said, God, fellas, I'm quite old.
The lion, he said, there's got to be the handouts.
However, in some ways, somehow,
they're all keeping it going, keep on rolling.
Then, oh, yeah, I was talking to Gilbo the other day,
stopped in there for coffee in the morning
when I thought for a walk.
He's keeping it fine.
Oh, he's mad at the government.
He did their own a bunch of things.
Then he said, listen, Vancouver is trying to negotiate a deal for her.
It was probably one of these machines to make steel bins.
And they had some complicated deal that he had a chance
to buy $15,000 worth of steel for $9,000.
And he couldn't find anybody that needed a bin.
So I guess that's put on the back burner.
Other than that, he didn't have anything to say about Denny.
And the farmers here are suffering.
Of course, they holler like hell.
It always was that way.
Farming was always a tough deal in Saskatchewan.
I remember when I was home on the farm,
the years that you went through with farming,
it got enough to pull you through.
But Dad never asked for anything.
We never got by extension to government.
Dad worked for 17 years.
And they never went to the municipality or anybody to get seed
or help or anything.
They always stayed on top of the pile.
Of course, he had a lot of the manpower around there to help us.
I suppose that didn't hurt any.
Although there were other families around there.
It was just this thing of families we had that never made it through at all.
After five, six years, they'd pull it up and head back to the States
when they couldn't.
That's the last you'd hear of them.
But farmers, sure, they're not going to make it big.
Those that brought land at $400, $500, $600 an acre,
they're in trouble.
There's no question about it.
You can't pay them for land and then sell wheat for $2.50 or $3 a bushel.
Right now, a lot of this grain,
where they have the big, heavy crop, particularly in the Regina area here,
if they didn't get it off before the rain,
it's going to go about 3, 4, 5 feet.
And they only get a couple dollars a bushel for it.
Well...
that doesn't count up very fast.
Those that got theirs off first,
I guess they get about better than $3 a bushel.
But their quota's only 2.9 bushels to the acre,
so they're only shallow enough to pay the gas bill,
and that's about all.
The banker and the implement company will have to wait.
Yesterday, Don Horstman, one of my Rummy friends,
picked me up right after work.
We went out for coffee.
The Rummy games haven't been going on for about 3 months now.
Bill Harkson, one of the stable, steady guys,
he's got vision problems the same as I have.
We're both about equal visually.
He's been in the hospital for almost 3 months now.
He's 81 years old, and he just had a stomach operation,
and his kidneys are gone.
He's in a hell of a shape.
He told me a month ago, he said,
I'll never get out of here.
He could be right,
but he's in a pretty bad shape.
He's pouring blood into him, and I hate him to him.
I'm going up to see him this afternoon.
He's been in intensive care.
I haven't seen him now for about 8 days.
Well, I have a chap.
I'm hard to miss with a guy,
and he's been laying in bed like that.
You know, they lose interest.
They don't have TV or radio or anything.
They sort of lose interest in what's going on in the outside world.
And what about the...
Oh, I guess we told you that Alan Akin,
Mac's wife, passed away.
Yes, we told you that.
And I was talking to Ethel.
At that time, I phoned Ethel to let her know about him.
She's keeping fine up in Edmonton.
Jimmy Lawrence getting married is, you know,
on the 6th of December.
You'll probably have an announcement.
He wasn't sending out invitations.
He said, we didn't expect you guys to come that far to...
Of course, it's the end of the afternoon at a wedding.
And he did the same with us.
He said, I don't expect you people to come up.
He said, it's...
A lot of pus there.
And this time of the year, and the weather's so uncertain,
I don't think that Wally and Willa are going up.
If anything, Wally may go.
But Willa, she settled down there.
She'd be feeling pretty good since she got back down there.
She was not in very good shape the last time she was up here,
which was just before the end of October.
She was...
Not herself at all.
She was thin and uninterested and hard to converse with.
But now, we talked to her on the phone the other night
on Wally's birthday, which was on the 17th of November.
She sounded really good.
She said she was feeling good, too.
And, oh, yeah, the big city of Halbright got on the news
right before last.
The guy that delivers mail from here down to Weyburn
and all the towns along the line,
to Estherland and I don't know how far beyond.
But when he's at Halbright about 5 o'clock in the morning,
I guess you must have a key to put the mail bags in the post office.
And two or three guys jumped him to come into the post office
and tied him up and took his truck, loaded the mail,
and went about nine miles to start the Halbright out into a field.
And lipping up all the mail bags and searching.
I guess they got a bunch of money that was to go up to the co-op
or credit unit in Estherland.
And they smashed the headlights on the truck, I don't know why,
and let it stand out in the field.
Somebody saw it, I guess, went out there and see what was happening
and called out it was the mail truck.
They have no clue of ever accepting from the driver who said,
that he thought there were three guys that jumped in and blindfolded him
and tied him up and put a rope around his neck to start with him.
He could be implicated in a thing too, you duck know.
Anyway, that's the way it goes.
The snow is all gone here except down on the north side of the building
with this river on it.
The backyard might be two inches.
All the streets are icy, the sidewalks are icy.
Didn't all melt.
Didn't totally disappear, sort of.
The sun can't get very high these days.
My God, I just said to the fellas the other day,
I said it's going to have to keep working pretty hard to stay above the horizon
by the 21st of December until we get up in the morning at 9 o'clock.
It's just barely showing up at 9 o'clock in the morning.
I don't know how it is with beef, how it's there farther south.
Yeah, you'd see quite a bit more,
more of it than they do here, where they used to go longer.
And that was all right.
Well, I got my reading machine.
Boy, I can really read the fine print with it.
When I was installing those parts on the water softer,
the print is so fine, you know.
And I'd put them there, and I could pull it up,
and I could read just as plain as anything.
So I opened my mail today, and the mail came in.
When I opened my letters, I was able to read the letters
and see what was in them.
So that's about to keep me busy.
I won't be spending so much time on the tape.
During the day, I don't pay any attention to TV,
excepting I get an hour of news at noon.
And then I don't bother with TV until half past five.
I try to run for the news from the Arctic.
And at six o'clock, the news comes on.
So I watch it about an hour.
And then I watch all these sports.
Football.
I'm still enjoying my football.
It's not much better on TV than it was up again.
I can just see all the red players.
I'm just going to stop for a minute.
I had to stop and clear my throat for a little while.
When I talk very much, my voice gets foggy.
Because I don't talk that much.
Around here, Phyllis and I are alone.
You don't get much talking.
So when you get a chance to talk,
for 10, 15 minutes straight,
your voice starts to fog you right away.
I know a fact.
Yesterday, when I was up at Euclid's,
sat there for half an hour talking,
and my voice almost totally
faltered by the time I left there.
And I think it's just from a lack of exercise.
I'll have to do some taping to myself
and play them back and erase them
and tape them over again.
Oh yeah, I'm sending these tapes to you.
That's a second version of my life's history.
I wasn't happy with the first one.
It was badly taped.
Anyway, Jane and Joe,
they've got the first version of it.
And then I took and I run that over
and re-ended the whole thing.
And that's what you're getting now.
And from Danning, it's a tape deck.
I'll send him one.
I'll send him a copy, too.
In the meantime, he can listen to yours.
That's four hours of tape.
I'm going,
you'll find some of it,
some of it sort of monotonous.
Ferland gave me,
he said,
you talked for four hours there.
You never mentioned one thing about your family.
I said, this was my life that I was talking about.
My working life.
Not that I,
not my family or the social side of my life.
It's my working life that I was taping it.
And I'm sure that Joe and Dan
will get quite a bit out of it,
having both worked for the company
and has some notion of what it's all about,
what goes on out there.
And yeah, what else?
Oh yeah, at Ellen's funeral,
Lyle and family were down there.
Yeah.
Lyle's still pretty,
pretty hefty
cell worker.
I don't want time that he's going to tape my
last story.
Early retirement,
but I guess he's still
able to carry on.
I don't know
what's going to happen to them.
They're still hanging on,
pushing the car in the heaven.
Back up behind him,
a cover.
Every once in a while,
you hear something about people.
They're in trouble.
They didn't refinance it.
Consumers refinance it.
Don't do this alone.
They keep throwing his stuff down there.
And I haven't heard from Mel.
I wrote him a long letter about
the whole part of the end of all this.
And he's still out there.
Lang may be a suitor,
that's the way it is.
Had a letter from
Ken and Peggy Williams.
They're heading south
for Palm Springs
for four months.
So normally,
if you want to find out something
about Palm Springs,
you can give them a call someday.
All they do is golf.
They get a place right by the golf course,
and I guess they tell the golf
what you call it,
membership for the four months of air,
and they're out in the golf course
every day.
I guess when you're tired,
and they see that you can golf all winter,
but it's just pretty wet.
And they have to put on rubber boots.
But they are in the golf course.
They'll go off and bat that ball around
even if it is bad.
On December the 9th,
he's got a letter to the
Central Line Contractors.
That's the one that I helped organize.
I was the first president
of the Central Line Contractors.
It's a statue.
They're having a,
they're hanging across the town at the hour
in a hotel in Saskatchewan
on December the 9th,
so that'll be an evening out for me.
Get to see and hear what's going on
in the power business.
I don't hear much.
It's all very quiet.
Bud Welts stopped in yesterday.
He's working in this area,
and he dropped in for a cup of coffee.
He's 57 years old.
He said, I can't wait till I'm 60.
I want to get out.
He said, retire at 60.
It's getting tougher every day.
The older you get,
he's in the gas department now.
To get down on your knees
and work on these gas furnaces
isn't any joke.
I keep,
I've seen them come into my place here,
and they have the guys there.
Get over here in crowded quarters
and ask you to get down on your knees.
It's hard work.
Bud was saying,
I haven't been off the shop.
I told you that that lumber
had burnt down.
Just the office portion
were burnt up,
and they knocked all the rest of it down.
There was nothing but a barrel
out there now.
Oh, we had some sad news
the day before yesterday.
Just said,
a clearance heard,
and his wife, Agnes,
died suddenly.
This was in the obituaries.
Died suddenly on November the 20th,
in the private funeral.
He has three daughters,
one in Hawaii,
one in White Rock, B.C.,
and one in Winnipeg,
and a private funeral,
and then it comes out
that his wife had Alzheimer's,
and Alzheimer's,
and arthritis very badly,
and he carried her out to the garage.
Now, this is a story we get,
but it's true or not.
Carried her out to the garage,
and put her in the backseat of the car,
and he got in the front seat
and started the motor up,
and kicked her out,
because that was it.
I don't know how long it would take
you to get gas out in the garage.
You would only have a single garage.
Probably wouldn't take very long.
So Clash put her down to it.
He was about 74 or 5 years old,
and you know who he was,
he was on the rupp DeLumber
across the point of Clemson.
I had known it for 20 years.
But I was in business there,
And, of course, another 20 cents that slid on him for about a quarter of a year.
Real nice type of a guy.
And quite a nice way to have him.
Good living.
And I guess the reason he went with her, they were a very close couple.
Died soon.
Throughout the years, he was quite a home man.
And I guess you couldn't take her anymore.
And Gordon South died.
I don't think Danny will have that in a letter.
He can't sell much of it.
Well, I guess he can if he's got a quota of 2.9 bushels per acre.
And that's for every cultivated acre you have.
So he could sell maybe most of his wheat.
The amount of acres he has cultivated between him and his boys.
They work in one big operation.
And he said he took him.
Last year, he took him $4,500 of oil.
And he doesn't own an oil well.
That was in surface rights.
They pay you $4,500 a well now.
And when they drill a well, I think they give you $5,000 or $6,000 for the initial year.
And then he had two or three dugouts.
And he's selling water.
Sells $1,000 worth of water.
Drill a well.
So he said that took him $45,000 of oil.
And don't own an oil well.
It's if the surface rights are gone.
So that helped him.
But he's had a tough, tough, tough time.
And it's expanding.
And a big family.
Want to keep the boys on the farm.
He had a family of 13, you know.
Same as we had.
And they lived on that same farm.
And they're all pretty well fed up.
The youngest one, maybe 12, 13 years old.
And when I was that age, I was doing a man's work around the farm.
And they'd be driving an outfit.
You'd shield your home with a foot shoe.
You know, hauling manure.
The whole world.
Feeding the cows.
Melting the cows.
Feeding the oxen.
You know, all your work.
$10 a day in a man's hands.
Unless you're at school.
I think I told Danny about cupping.
I haven't heard a word about hunting for two years now.
Except Kevin Murphy, I know, goes out for a deer every year.
But I never see him.
I had a small friend that hit him.
And I'd see up to the elk's.
And they're going out.
And I'd see up to the elk's down around East End for mule deer.
And this fella goes with a calvin tenner.
And the old Murphy, oldest Murphy girl, had her second baby just the end of the year.
About two babies, or about one year.
I can't tell you what's up with it.
He had 12, 13 bunches.
And the other one, Pat, she was working as a nurse.
She had a sick fellow a while back.
She wasn't going to work.
But I'd see her parrots around.
I'd say, I guess you should not do it.
Nothing else.
Chains in the navel.
I'd never see the cernyx.
I saw Kenny and Mr. Cernyx about six weeks ago.
I was out for a walk.
I went down Sunset.
And Kenny was out doing something to his car.
And I went over and talked to him.
I talked to him quite a while before.
I thought it was Wayne.
I had talked to him quite a while before.
I said, you're Kenny.
And he said, yeah.
And he said, I didn't think you recognized me.
I had poor eyesight again.
Mr. Cernyx had to come out to ask him to check on the cattines there.
I had a few words with him.
I thought, the brown boys haven't heard a thing all the year,
maybe a year and a half.
But Damien dropped it here one day.
And I wasn't home.
And he goes into the village.
I don't know if he was with us, but I don't know.
But I understand he's the head Maitre D at the gulps.
Unless he's changed into one of the orcs.
And that's sort of climbing up the ladder in a hurry.
I can't see in it because they made the free head in the evil little.
They saw I kept creating a giant .
Boy, I guess if I saw the way with the people,
I'd have bought the ladder.
I'm not talking very fast, though. I might as well keep this thing going because you have to run it to the end anyway to get back to Cape Plough.
So I can't think of anything else to say. What to say?
Uh, yeah, the girls. Linda called the other night wanting to know how to make dough for apple pie. A crust.
She was trying to probably get the stick together. I couldn't believe it. At her age, she didn't know how to make a pie crust.
Well, I spoke to her and she did all the motions because it was over a telephone still.
I had to hold it all in. It was Linda. How you had to work it and everything.
Well, we didn't hear any more about that.
Fenton Jackson and I had to go down and flip the window back to pay my bills.
I was playing about four or five days before the end of the month. Thank goodness.
They almost stopped serving it right when I was there.
But the time is, it's going on to two o'clock, yeah.
Going on to two o'clock and shortly we'll be pulling out.
Come what might.
I don't know. I've been feeling good.
I walked, yesterday I walked 15 blocks.
Yesterday morning when I left for, walked out to Canadian Cire.
Well, first I walked, yeah, I walked for the bus to North McCarthy.
By the time I get in for coffee, I walk up to the Optimist Club. That's four blocks.
They catch the bus.
And then by the time I get in for coffee, that's six blocks.
Then I come from another bus and went down to Canadian Cire.
And then I went up to see Hugo and Kelly, had coffee there.
And I hope I figured out I had walked 15 blocks.
And it didn't bother me a bit.
But today I walked just about the same.
I walked down to Canadian Cire and back again.
That amounts to about 14 blocks.
My legs are standing up good.
In fact, I get some muscles that hard me up.
But they're always so flabby.
Now they're stopped.
It's the muscles.
I'm keeping my weight up.
I'm probably up to 15 pounds right now.
The way my hands seem thin.
I can't see the scales, so they're not beating me.
Don't let me look like that.
That's why Paula Phillips there could tell me how much I weigh.
And I think she'd probably not tell me the truth.
But she ought to have told you I should put on more weight.
But I said, yeah, I don't have to.
They don't apply to new employees.
Or else get them readjusting around the race band.
So I said, I'm heavy enough.
When Bud Waltz saw me yesterday.
He was here when I came in from coffee.
And he looked happy.
He said, boy, you could paint some of Phyllis's excess weight around you.
And you'd look better.
And she could look better.
But I don't know.
I didn't say anything.
But as we stepped, the light could sound better.
And the next shot wrapped him.
The ride could not have any weight.
It's nothing right now.
It's a midnight.
And this bachelor slapped up at the breakfast table and at the supper table with Trevor.
We're all set now.
We're going to break up on Saturday.
I'm afraid that I'm going to have trouble with that kid.
And I'm going to be pretty solid up down there on a supporter batch.
And he's a diamond on me.
He's copied from Moon to run him with the ball.
They asked Parker to last day.
Don't you worry about him when he runs like that.
He said, that's the way.
You watch your play.
That's the only way.
They let us go.
So far, so good.
But Hamilton played one hell of a game against .
Yes.
But to both their clubs, it didn't happen.
I think the other night in Miami, .
Three points to .45.
It went thrashing based and rocked up.
Don't mean anything.
Wood dollies.
Well, that was the thing.
The harvest line, you know, that's when everything happened.
It pushed me into something, too.
For a young fellow like me to go to Raleigh about 19 years ago, started one-hand
thrashing machinery.
And it was always the story to go around that this guy never, the machine never stops, right?
Now he's stopping half the time.
But if you were an operator, everybody in the country knew you.
There's no question about that.
And as I've said right now, we've all been taught before that I always separate the grain
clean.
When they start cuffing in the elevators, the elevator man couldn't believe how much
rain would come that came out of a crash in the team.
It happened to me.
The only way you would go up is you'd thrash it.
Now that's not a cure.
You keep working at it until you get it.
You've got everything stuck in there.
It came out to us.
What do you think?
Have a note?
I'll talk with you again about taking notes about this and about that.
I can give you the details.
Raleigh said, oh, can you remember back to the year?
Let's make it the event of the year.
I said, I don't know.
I can see.
If I were in beauty, you know, things would happen 40, 50 years from now or something.
And remember the dates of that thing.
No problem.
That's the end of it.
I had to wreck those things.
I had to wreck them.
I had the thing like hell.
That hit me.
Can you remember when I pushed up the last bike?
That was part of growing old.
Oh, yeah.
I had a letter from Cascade, Iowa from the cousins that were up here this summer.
And they mentioned about Uncle Hiller that was my mother's youngest brother who was still
living at 104 years of age.
He fell last spring and cracked his hip.
But the back got blocky again.
The boot.
His mind, I guess, was sort of a hit the brain a bit.
So she said, I had put a message in the letter to her for her dad.
And she read it out to him.
She said he couldn't remember much about the Aikens and Captain Lorry.
Well, that's the other stuff.
He and Lorry were just about the same age.
So his memory must be failing a bit.
Which one can I expect?
I bet he.
It marked him.
He was never a strong man before he was on the trail often.
Because I remember the back of 1925 when I first met him.
He had a footballed arm.
One-hooked arm.
The arbor was such a .
He used that one.
He could tip.
He was a good drinker.
He could tip a drink.
But on the other hand, he was a frail looking man, man.
He could not navigate over .
